poem_title: An English BALLAD, On the Taking of NAMUR By the King of Great Britain, 1695.
author: Matthew Prior
poem_alt_title: On the Taking of NAMUR By the King of Great Britain , 1695.

lines.line_text: Folks are drunk, yet do not know it:
So might not  give You Law?
Was it a Muse, O lofty Poet,
Or Virgin of St. , You saw?
Why all this Fury? What's the Matter,
That Oaks must come from  to dance?
Must stupid Stocks be taught to flatter?
And is there no such Wood in
Why must the Winds all hold their Tongue?
If they a little Breath should raise;
Would that have spoil'd the Poet's Song;
Or puff'd away the Monarch's Praise?

stanzas.stanza_text:
Folks are drunk, yet do not know it:
So might not  give You Law?
Was it a Muse, O lofty Poet,
Or Virgin of St. , You saw?
Why all this Fury? What's the Matter,
That Oaks must come from  to dance?
Must stupid Stocks be taught to flatter?
And is there no such Wood in
Why must the Winds all hold their Tongue?
If they a little Breath should raise;
Would that have spoil'd the Poet's Song;
Or puff'd away the Monarch's Praise?

lines.line_text: , that Eagle, mounts the Skies;
While Virtue leads the noble Way:
Too like a Vultur  flies,
Where sordid Interest shows the Prey.
When once the Poet's Honour ceases,
From Reason far his Transports rove:
And , for eight hundred Pieces,
Makes  take the Wall of .

lines.line_text: and  came from above,
Shap'd like  and :
They arm'd these Rocks; then show'd old
Of  Wood, the Wond'rous Plan.
Such Walls, these three wise Gods agreed,
By Human Force could ne'er be shaken:
But You and I in  read
Of Gods, as well as Men, mistaken.
and  their Waves may join;
But ne'er can  Force restrain:
He'll pass them Both, who pass'd the :
Remember this, and arm the .

lines.line_text: Full fifteen thousand lusty Fellows
With Fire and Sword the Fort maintain:
Each was a , You tell us;
Yet out they march'd like common Men.
Cannons above, and Mines below
Did Death and Tombs for Foes contrive:
Yet Matters have been order'd so,
That most of Us are still alive.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Full fifteen thousand lusty Fellows
With Fire and Sword the Fort maintain:
Each was a , You tell us;
Yet out they march'd like common Men.
Cannons above, and Mines below
Did Death and Tombs for Foes contrive:
Yet Matters have been order'd so,
That most of Us are still alive.

lines.line_text: If  be compar'd to ;
Then  Boys excell'd the :
Their Siege did ten long Years employ:
We've done our Bus'ness in ten Weeks.
What Godhead does so fast advance,
With dreadful Pow'r those Hills to gain?
'Tis little , the Scourge of ;
No Godhead, but the first of Men.
His mortal Arm exerts the Pow'r,
To keep ev'n  Victor under:
And that same  no more
Shall fright the World with impious Thunder.

stanzas.stanza_text:
If  be compar'd to ;
Then  Boys excell'd the :
Their Siege did ten long Years employ:
We've done our Bus'ness in ten Weeks.
What Godhead does so fast advance,
With dreadful Pow'r those Hills to gain?
'Tis little , the Scourge of ;
No Godhead, but the first of Men.
His mortal Arm exerts the Pow'r,
To keep ev'n  Victor under:
And that same  no more
Shall fright the World with impious Thunder.

lines.line_text: Our King thus trembles at ,
Whilst , who ne'er afraid is,
To  marches on secure,
To bomb the Monks, and scare the Ladies.
After this glorious Expedition,
One Battle makes the Marshal Great:
He must perform the King's Commission:
Who knows, but  may retreat?
Kings are allow'd to feign the Gout,
Or be prevail'd with not to Fight:
And mighty  hop'd, no doubt,
That  wou'd preserve that Right.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Our King thus trembles at ,
Whilst , who ne'er afraid is,
To  marches on secure,
To bomb the Monks, and scare the Ladies.
After this glorious Expedition,
One Battle makes the Marshal Great:
He must perform the King's Commission:
Who knows, but  may retreat?
Kings are allow'd to feign the Gout,
Or be prevail'd with not to Fight:
And mighty  hop'd, no doubt,
That  wou'd preserve that Right.

lines.line_text: From  and , to  and ,
See every Mother's Son appear:
In such a Case ne'er blame a Foe,
If he betrays some little Fear.
He comes, the mighty  comes;
Finds a small River in his Way:
So waves his Colours, beats his Drums;
And thinks it prudent there to stay.
The  Troops breath Blood and War:
The Marshal cares not to march faster:
Poor  moves so slowly here,
We fancy'd all, it was his Master.

stanzas.stanza_text:
From  and , to  and ,
See every Mother's Son appear:
In such a Case ne'er blame a Foe,
If he betrays some little Fear.
He comes, the mighty  comes;
Finds a small River in his Way:
So waves his Colours, beats his Drums;
And thinks it prudent there to stay.
The  Troops breath Blood and War:
The Marshal cares not to march faster:
Poor  moves so slowly here,
We fancy'd all, it was his Master.

lines.line_text: Will no kind Flood, no friendly Rain
Disguise the Marshal's plain Disgrace?
No Torrents swell the low ?
The World will say, he durst not pass.
Why will no  appear,
Dear Poet, on the Banks of ?
Just as they did that mighty Year,
When You turn'd  into .
The Water- are too unkind
To ; are the Land- so?
And fly They All, at Once Combin'd
To shame a General, and a Beau?

Just as they did that mighty Year,
When You turn'd  into .
The Water- are too unkind
To ; are the Land- so?
And fly They All, at Once Combin'd
To shame a General, and a Beau?

lines.line_text: Truth, Justice, Sense, Religion, Fame
May join to finish  Story:
Nations set free may bless his Name;
And  in Secret own his Glory.
But , and ,
, St. ,
, and   Ye Criticks, say,
How poor to this was  Style?
With Eke's and Also's tack thy Strain,
Great Bard; and sing the deathless Prince,
Who lost  the same Campaign,
He bought , and plunder'd .

lines.line_text: I'll hold Ten Pound, my Dream is out:
I'd tell it You, but for the Rattle
Of those confounded Drums: no doubt
Yon' bloody Rogues intend a Battel.
Dear me! a hundred thousand
With Terror fill the neighb'ring Field;
While  carries on the Trench,
'Till both the Town and Castle yield.
to  should advance,
Says , thro' Cannons Mouths in Fire;
, one Mareschal of
Tells t'other, He can come no nigher.

I'll hold Ten Pound, my Dream is out:
I'd tell it You, but for the Rattle
Of those confounded Drums: no doubt
Yon' bloody Rogues intend a Battel.
Dear me! a hundred thousand
With Terror fill the neighb'ring Field;
While  carries on the Trench,
'Till both the Town and Castle yield.
to  should advance,
Says , thro' Cannons Mouths in Fire;
, one Mareschal of
Tells t'other, He can come no nigher.

lines.line_text: Regain the Lines the shortest Way,
; or to  take Post:
For, having seen it, Thou can'st say
The Steps, by which  was lost.
The Smoke and Flame may vex thy Sight:
Look not once back: but as thou goest,
Quicken the Squadrons in their Flight;
And bid the Dl take the slowest.
Think not what Reason to produce,
From  to conceal thy Fear:
He'll own the Strength of thy Excuse;
Tell him that  was but there.

stanzas.stanza_text:

; or to  take Post:
For, having seen it, Thou can'st say
The Steps, by which  was lost.
The Smoke and Flame may vex thy Sight:
Look not once back: but as thou goest,
Quicken the Squadrons in their Flight;
And bid the Dl take the slowest.
Think not what Reason to produce,
From  to conceal thy Fear:
He'll own the Strength of thy Excuse;
Tell him that  was but there.

lines.line_text: Now let us look for Feather,
That us'd to shine so like a Star:
The Gen'rals could not get together,
Wanting that Influence, great in War.
O Poet! Thou had'st been discreeter,
Hanging the Monarch's Hat so high;
If Thou had'st dubb'd thy Star, a Meteor,
That did but blaze, and rove, and die.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now let us look for Feather,
That us'd to shine so like a Star:
The Gen'rals could not get together,
Wanting that Influence, great in War.
O Poet! Thou had'st been discreeter,
Hanging the Monarch's Hat so high;
If Thou had'st dubb'd thy Star, a Meteor,
That did but blaze, and rove, and die.

lines.line_text: To animate the doubtful Fight,
in vain expects that Ray:
In vain  hopes, the sickly Light
Shou'd shine near  fuller Day.
It knows , it's proper Station;
Nor cares for any foreign Sphere:
Where You see  Constellation,
Be sure no Danger can be near.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To animate the doubtful Fight,
in vain expects that Ray:
In vain  hopes, the sickly Light
Shou'd shine near  fuller Day.
It knows , it's proper Station;
Nor cares for any foreign Sphere:
Where You see  Constellation,
Be sure no Danger can be near.

lines.line_text: The  had gather'd all their Force;
And  met them in their Way:
Yet off they brush'd, both Foot and Horse.
What has Friend  left to say?
When his high Muse is bent upon't,
To sing her King, that Great Commander,
Or on the Shores of ,
Or in the Valleys near ;
Wou'd it not spoil his noble Task,
If any foolish  there is,
Impertinent enough to ask,
How far  may be from

lines.line_text: Two Stanza's more before we end,
Of Death, Pikes, Rocks, Arms, Bricks, and Fire:
Leave 'em behind You, honest Friend:
And with your Country-Men retire.
Your Ode is spoilt;  is freed;
For  something yet is due:
So good Count  may proceed;
But , Sir, one Word with you.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Two Stanza's more before we end,
Of Death, Pikes, Rocks, Arms, Bricks, and Fire:
Leave 'em behind You, honest Friend:
And with your Country-Men retire.
Your Ode is spoilt;  is freed;
For  something yet is due:
So good Count  may proceed;
But , Sir, one Word with you.

lines.line_text: 'Tis done. In Sight of these Commanders,
Who neither Fight, nor raise the Siege,
The Foes of  march safe thro' ;
Divide to , or to .
Send, , this News to ;
That  may new Honours gain:
He the same Play by Land has shown,
As  did upon the Main.
Yet is the Marshal made a Peer:
, may thy Arms advance;
That He may lose  next Year,
And so be Constable of .
